questions.question:
Question 1: Which is the process designed to prevent microorganisms from reaching a protected 
environment?
questions.explanation:
Asepsis is the process designed to prevent microorganisms from reaching a protected 
environment. Sterilization is a process of killing or removal of all living microorganisms either in the vegetative 
or spore state from an area or surface or a medium. Decontamination is the process of rendering an article or area free of contaminants, including 
microbial, chemical, radioactive and other hazardous materials. Disinfection is the process by which the destruction of microorganisms is achieved with the use of 
physical or chemical agents. Microbial forms like spores and some viruses may be resistant to 
certain disinfectants.

questions.question: Question 2: All of the following are methods of dry heat sterilisation except:
questions.explanation:
Autoclaving is a method of moist heat sterilization. Dry heat sterilization 
Moist heat sterilization BoilingPasteurizationAutocla 
ving FlamingIncinerationHot air o 
ven

questions.question:
Question 3: What is the temperature that has to be maintained for sterilization in the device shown 
below? 175 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image shown is a sterilizing hot air oven. The temperature to be maintained is 160° C for 2 
hours. Exposure to dry heat in a sterilizing hot air oven ensures the carbonization of organic material 
and the destruction of microorganisms and spores. The following combinations of temperature 
and duration of sterilization can be applied in hot air ovens: • 180°C for 30 mins • 170°C for 60 mins • 160■C for 2 hours

questions.question:
Question 4: An OT technician is sterilizing surgical instruments in the following device. What 
temperature should be maintained?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows an autoclave. Surgical instruments are sterilized at 121° C for 10-15 
minutes. 183 
Sold by @itachibot Autoclaving is a form of moist heat sterilization which creates an increased temperature of steam 
under pressure. This method of sterilization is effective against spores also. Autoclaving is done 
for instruments that cannot withstand high temperatures of hot air oven or dry heat.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following materials are sterilized by a hot air oven?
questions.explanation: Glasswares, oils and powders, swabs, and dressings are sterilized by a hot air oven. Surgical instruments and culture media are sterilized by autoclave.

questions.question:
Question 6: Šou have performed an upper GI endoscopy on a HbsAg positive patient. Which of the 
following should be used to sterilize the scope?
questions.explanation: 2% glutaraldehyde is used to sterilize endoscopes and fibreoptic scopes. Aldehydes in 2% solutions (like glutaraldehyde and formaldehyde) have sporicidal activities. Glutaraldehyde is usually efficacious against tubercle bacteria, fungi & viruses.

questions.question:
Question 7: Which of the following is false regarding the use of ethylene oxide in sterilisation and 
disinfection?

options.a: It is an inflammable and explosive gas
options.b: It is used for heat-sensitive objects
options.c: It is mixed with nitrogen for sterilization

questions.explanation:
A mixture of ethylene oxide with carbon dioxide is used for sterilization, not with nitrogen. Ethylene oxide is an alkylating agent and has inflammable and explosive properties. It is often 
mixed with the following prior to use: • Carbon dioxide - decreases its explosive nature • Water vapor - increases the efficiency of the gas Sterilization using this gas is usually done at 50-60 °C. and is suitable for heat-sensitive items like 
plastics, heart valves, dental equipment. It is effective against bacteria, spores, and some viruses.

questions.question:
Question 8: The following machine was used during a cardiac bypass surgery. How is it best sterilized? 177 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image shown is a heart-lung machine. It is best sterilized using ethylene oxide. Ethylene oxide gas diffuses through many types of porous materials and readily penetrates some 
plastics and is used for sterilizing machines.

questions.question: Question 9: Povidone - iodine is an example of:
questions.explanation:
Povidone - iodine is an iodophor. 184 
Sold by @itachibot Iodophors are iodine-based disinfectants in which iodine is combined with solubilizing agents or 
carriers. This results in the formation of a complex that provides a sustained release reservoir of 
iodine and releases small amounts of free iodine in an aqueous solution.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is an example of precurrent disinfection?

options.a: Chlorination of a well by village public health authorities
options.b: Disinfection of kidney tray used during delivery of placenta
options.c: Disinfection of bed linen after the death of a patient
options.d: Disinfection of artery forceps following a surgery

questions.explanation:
Chlorination of water in a well is an example of precurrent disinfection. Precurrent disinfection refers to prophylactic disinfection prior to discharge of infectious material. 
This includes pasteurization of milk, chlorination of water and hand washing. Concurrent disinfection is the application of disinfection methods after discharge of infectious 
material from a person or soiling. This includes disinfection of urine, faeces, vomit, contaminated 
linen, clothes, hands. Terminal disinfection is done after the death of a patient or transfer or after cessation of isolation.

questions.question: Question 11: Chlorine is the main disinfectant element in all of the following except:
questions.explanation:
Cetrimide (trade name - Cetavlon) is a quaternary ammonia compound (QAC) that does not 
contain chlorine. QACs are low-level disinfectants and are sporostatic but not sporicidal. It is a 
bactericidal agent against vegetative gram-positive organisms. Other QACs include cetrimide (cetavlon) and benzalkonium chloride. Savlon contains cetrimide and chlorhexidine and is mainly used for plastic 
items. Clinical thermometers may be best disinfected in Savlon mixed with spirit in a 1:6 ratio. Chlorine compounds are potent disinfectants that are bactericidal, fungicidal, sporicidal, 
tuberculocidal, and virucidal. Chlorine compounds

Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 12: Hydrogen peroxide is:
questions.explanation:
Hydrogen peroxide is effective against bacteria, fungi, spores and viruses. It is used in the hospital setting to disinfect surfaces. Sporicidal activities require higher 
concentrations and longer contact times. A 3% solution is also used as an antiseptic and for 
cleaning wounds and discharging ulcers.

questions.question: Question 13: Which among the following is a low-level disinfectant?
questions.explanation:
Benzalkonium chloride is a quaternary ammonium compound that is used as a low-level 
disinfectant. There are 3 types of disinfectants: • Low-level disinfectant - kills only vegetative bacteria, fungi and lipid enveloped viruses (e.g. 
quaternary ammonium compounds) • Intermediate level disinfectant: kills all microbes including mycobacteria and non-enveloped 
viruses, but not spores (e.g. alcohol, iodophors) • High-level disinfectant - This is a chemical that kills all microbial pathogens and some spores if 
the contact time is increased (e.g. glutaraldehyde, hydrogen peroxide)

questions.question: Question 14: Which among the following is not a sporicidal agent?
questions.explanation:
Cresol a phenolic compound is not sporicidal. Disinfectants that are not sporicidal are: • Biguanides • Alcohols • Heavy metal disinfectants • Organic acids • QACs • Phenolic compounds Sporicidal disinfectants include: • Aldehydes • Chlorine disinfectants • Hydrogen peroxide • Ethylene oxide 186 
Sold by @itachibot • Peracetic acids

questions.question:
Question 15: 179 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following disinfectants has anti-viral action?
questions.explanation: Hypochlorite is an antiviral disinfectant. Antiviral disinfectants include: • Chlorine compounds • Phenol (at high concentrations) • Aldehydes • Hydrogen peroxide

questions.question:
Question 16: A nurse in a PHC is using bleaching powder to disinfect bed linen contaminated with stool. 
What is the amount that she should use?
questions.explanation:
Bleaching powder of 50 g/L of water is required for disinfecting feces and urine. The agents commonly used for disinfecting faeces and urine are: Disinfectant

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following methods of disinfection is not effective against prions?
questions.explanation: Benzalkonium chloride is not effective against prions. Prions can be inactivated by following the given steps: • Immersing the instruments in 1N NaOH or sodium hypochlorite for 1 hour • Then they are transferred to water • Then they are heated in a gravity displacement autoclave at 121°C for 1 hour • After this, they are cleaned and subjected to routine sterilization

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following methods is not effective for disinfection of sputum of patients?
questions.explanation:
187 
Sold by @itachibot Chlorhexidine is not used to disinfect sputum. Sputum can be disinfected by: • Autoclaving or boiling - if a considerable amount of sputum is present (e.g. in TB hospitals) • 5% cresol - patients are asked to spit in a sputum cup half-filled with cresol • Burning - for samples received in gauze or paper handkerchiefs

questions.question: Question 20: Rideal-Walker co-efficient is employed for the assessment of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
The Rideal-Walker coefficient helps in assessing the power of a disinfectant relative to phenol. It assesses this by determining the phenol coefficient (PC). A PC value of > 1 indicates that it is 
more effective than phenol. The higher the number, the greater its effectiveness in comparison to 
phenol and vice versa. Traditional organisms used to test the power of the disinfectant 
include S. aureus and Salmonella enteric subtype typhi. Phenol coefficient = The dilution of test disinfectant which kills microorganisms in a given 
time ÷ The dilution of phenol which kills the microorganism in the same time under identical 
conditions. 188 
Sold by @itachibot Other tests that are used for disinfectants are as follows: • Chick Martin test - modification of the Rideal-Walker test where disinfectants act in the presence 
of organic matter like feces or yeast to simulate natural conditions • Kelsey-Skyes test (capacity test) - tests the capacity of a disinfectant to retain its activity when 
used repeatedly. • In-use test - determines whether the chosen disinfectant is effective in actual hospital use Joseph Lister first introduced phenol (carbolic acid) as an antiseptic to sterilize surgical 
instruments and clean wounds. Lister's work led to a reduction in postoperative infections and 
made surgery safer for patients, distinguishing him as the 'Father of Modern Surgery' and 'Father 
of Antiseptic Surgery'.

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following is false regarding the Spaulding classification?

options.a: Semi-critical items require high level disinfection
options.b: Non-critical items do not require disinfection
options.c: Cardiac catheters are classified as critical items
options.d: Critical items are associated with a high risk of infection

questions.explanation:
Under the Spaulding classification, non-critical items require intermediate or low-level 
disinfection.

questions.question:
Question 22: While collecting blood for samples, you have spilled some on the floor. What would be the 
immediate next step?

options.a: Call the infection control team of the hospital

questions.explanation:
The immediate next step in this scenario is to clean the spilled blood with absorbable material. This absorbable material is then discarded in the yellow bin. Following this, sodium 
hypochlorite solution is used to decontaminate the surface. The concentrations of sodium 
hypochlorite used are: • < 10 mL blood spill - 1:100 dilution to decontaminate non-porous surfaces • > 10 mL blood spill or culture spill - 1:10 dilution for the first application, followed by 1:100 
dilution

questions.question:
Question 23: 181 
Sold by @itachibot A blood spill in the operation theatre must be cleaned with  
.
questions.explanation:
Sodium hypochlorite, a compound of chlorine, is the best disinfectant for surface blood spills. It is 
used with a concentration of 0.5-5%. If the spill contains large amounts of blood or body fluids, clean the visible matter with disposable 
absorbent material and discard the contaminated materials in appropriate, labelled containment. A 1:10–1:100 dilution of 5.25%–6.15% sodium hypochlorite (i.e., household bleach) or an 
EPA-registered tuberculocidal disinfectant has been recommended for decontaminating blood 
spills. 189 
Sold by @itachibot Screening
